Matt and all,

The book on the page you refer to is a Kanie-Nobuie exhibiti=
on piece that
has a number of high quality loose plates like those shown.

=
The book Arnold referred to is Kyusaku Akiyama's "Nakamura Kakudaifu Nobuie=

Tsuba shu [Collection of Rubbings of Nobuie's Sword Guards Belonging to
Ka=
kudaifu Nakamura]" from 1926 and I think several reprints. Many of the
Nobu=
ie guards we see, including Cary's that was written up in the English
editi=
on Token Bijitsu, are in that book. All illustrations are rubbings that
Aki=
yama made, which are actually more useful for study than many of the
photog=
raphs we see. Many of the guards in the book were destroyed during the
war.=
 While the current scholarship as to the generations and authenticity of
No=
buie signatures has changed since it's publication, it is still a very
usef=
ul and interesting book.

I have a copy for sale on my website, though it i=
s a bit pricey considering
it is from  Lundgren's library, and contains not=
es transcribed in 1964 by
Robert E. Haynes from the notes he made in 1961 w=
hile studying in Japan with
Dr. Torigoye.

Craig

Craig L. Harris          =

Hi Arnold, thanks for the response. Did =
you mean the book that these scans
came from? http://www.jpsword.com/files/=
kn/nobuiye.html
This webpage is very good for making side by side compariso=
ns with the pix
on Mr. Weissberg's website. I think I can see the sutble di=
fferences in the
mei now, or perhaps I want to believe I can *grin*. Some m=
ore pointers in
this direction might be good for me all the same. Are there=
 any specifics to
look for besides the 'softness'?

With regards to the Aki=
yama tsuba that was found, the mind boggles how it
wound up on a table at a=
 sword show in the US among a pile of other tsuba!

Matt

Ps. I know I shou=
ldn't ask, but who was the lucky finder?
